q: What are the typical symptoms of testicular cancer?
a: The typical symptoms of testicular cancer are a painless swelling or lump in one of the testicles, or any change in shape or texture of the testicles.

q: How can I detect testicular cancer?
i: You should be aware of what feels normal for you. Get to know your body and see a GP if you notice any changes.
a: You should be aware of what feels normal for you. Get to know your body and see a GP if you notice any changes.

q: What are the types of testicular cancer?
a: The different types of testicular cancer are classified by the type of cells the cancer begins in. The most common type is germ cell testicular cancer, which accounts for around 95% of all cases.

q: What is the most common subtype of germ cell testicular cancer?
a: The most common subtype of germ cell testicular cancer is seminomas, which have become more common in the past 20 years and now account for 40 to 45% of testicular cancers.

q: What is the role of the testicles in the male reproductive system?
a: The testicles are an important part of the male reproductive system because they produce sperm and the hormone testosterone, which plays a major role in male sexual development.

q: How common is testicular cancer?
a: Testicular cancer is a relatively rare type of cancer, accounting for just 1% of all cancers that occur in men.

q: What are the causes of testicular cancer?
a: The exact cause or causes of testicular cancer are unknown, but factors such as undescended testicles, family history, and previous testicular cancer increase the risk.

q: What is the outlook for testicular cancer?
a: Testicular cancer is one of the most treatable types of cancer, with high survival rates. Almost all men (99%) survive for a year or more after diagnosis, and 98% survive for 5 years or more.

q: Does testicular cancer affect fertility or the ability to have sex?
a: The surgical removal of the affected testicle, which is a common treatment for testicular cancer, does not usually affect fertility or the ability to have sex.

q: Where can I find more information about testicular cancer?
a: You can find more information about testicular cancer from reputable sources such as Cancer Research UK or by consulting with a healthcare professional.

q: What are the typical symptoms of testicular cancer?
a: The typical symptoms of testicular cancer include a painless swelling or lump in one of the testicles, or any change in shape or texture of the testicles.

q: What is the function of the testicles in the male reproductive system?
a: The testicles are an important part of the male reproductive system as they produce sperm and the hormone testosterone, which plays a major role in male sexual development.

q: What are the two main subtypes of germ cell testicular cancer?
a: The two main subtypes of germ cell testicular cancer are seminomas and non-seminomas.

q: What is the most common type of testicular cancer?
a: The most common type of testicular cancer is germ cell testicular cancer, accounting for around 95% of all cases.

q: How common is testicular cancer?
a: Testicular cancer is a relatively rare type of cancer, accounting for just 1% of all cancers that occur in men. Around 2,300 men are diagnosed with testicular cancer each year in the UK.

q: What factor increases the risk of developing testicular cancer?
a: Undescended testicles (cryptorchidism) is the most significant risk factor for testicular cancer.

q: How does having a family history of testicular cancer affect the risk?
a: Having a close relative with a history of testicular cancer increases the risk of developing it. For example, if your father had testicular cancer, you're around 4 times more likely to develop it.

q: What is the outlook for testicular cancer?
a: Testicular cancer is one of the most treatable types of cancer. Almost all men (99%) survive for a year or more after diagnosis, and 98% survive for 5 years or more after diagnosis.

q: What is the main treatment for testicular cancer?
a: The main treatment for testicular cancer is the surgical removal of the affected testicle (orchidectomy or orchiectomy), which usually does not affect fertility or sexual function.

q: What can be used as additional treatments for seminomas?
a: In some cases, chemotherapy or, less commonly, radiotherapy may be used as additional treatments for seminomas (but not non-seminomas).
